title: Sensor-based single-user activity recognition

author: Blaž Kažič, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: I would like to present you my work that I have been researching with Jan Rupnick during this summer.
The title is sensor based, single user activity recognition.
Basically the goal of my research was to recognize activity in my case sitting, walking and running just with accelerometer data from the smartphone.
So.
A little motivation.
While this is interesting, the smartphone technology is constantly improving and with that also the sensors that are built in are getting better and better and cheaper.
It was interesting for me that couple weeks ago when Apple introduced the new iPhone 5S, they have added additional processor scene right here that is there just to process data from.
From sensors like accelerometer, GPS and Gyroscope to do exactly this so activity recognition.
So why?
Maybe this information useful first application where this could be useful is healthcare.
Nike, for example has developed mobile app where you can track your activity.
Also, you can then compare your activity with your friends in gaming center.
Another interesting application would be in business because with this information you can easily profile the user.
So this can be easily used for target advertising.
And another is.
Actually, from Phil that I am working my diploma research thesis and it is the localization with probabilistic methods.

So the problem for localization is that every sensors has some amount of uncertainties, so we cannot never tell for sure where we are located and if we look at this problem with probability methods and we look at this problem as based network or hidden Markov models where the hidden states are the actual positions and the measurements of the actual position is the GPS coordinate.
This can be additional information, so our our activity can be additional information.
For example, if the system knows that currently we are sitting, it will be highly unlikely that in the next state we will be we will move for 10 meters.
In contrast, if the system knows that we are driving in a car for example, this will be highly likely.
So the outline of my presentation will be the same as the workflow was.
First I had to collect the data from my phone.
Next I had to extract feature from raw data.
Next I had to select the classifier that would work the best in this case and for the end I will represent results of application.
How?
Tops.
So to collect data, first we had in mind to to develop our own own app.
But after a brief look on the Apple Store and Android Market, we have seen that a lot of these kind of applications are already built and are almost all free.
So it was just a matter of picking one.
In my case we used sensor logger.
This application allows me to store data from the accelerometer.
Alright, can live streaming via UDP packages.
I am streaming this data with 30 Hertz of frequency and here we can look the raw data from accelerometer.
And one sample represents 300 streams and it's 10 seconds long.
So altogether for the training data set, we have asked seven different people to perform all three different activities for around 15 minutes.
This altogether is 1750 samples and around five hours of data.
But before I can, we could extract features of this data we had to deal with one problem and this problem is orientation problem.
The problem is that everybody wears telephone differently.
We can wear it like this like this like this in pockets.
And because the accelerometer sensor is a 3D sensor, which means that we are getting data from XY and Z axis.
This shows and we can see here three different persons wearing differently phone but.
Are performing the same activities sitting in this actual in this case, and the data are completely different.
One easy solution for this is to think about this data is vectors and just compute the magnitude.
And here on the lower graph we can see that although the position was different, the graph is more or less the same, which is good since the activities.
The same.
We can also look at some of the other graphs of the other activities.
For example walking and running.
We can clearly see that the amplitude for walking is a lot larger than 4.
Four seating can also even larger for running.
But if we look at closer, we can also see that The Walking and the running graph is periodical.
And actually we can even we can even see what is the period.
And for The Walking case it's 0.5 seconds, usually an for the running it's 0.3 seconds.
So extracting features from this data we had in mind quite a lot of features.
But after awhile we we saw that some of these features do not provide any useful new information.
For example, the variance is just quadratic form of the standard deviation, so it doesn't really use.
Really have any more information.

Also, some features can be distracting for classifier, so it was really necessary to pick only the features that contributed most, so that's why we we designed this other feature set for simplified feature set.
These are actually selected features with Vika Tool Key that I will be presenting a little later and also the third feature set.
It is only consists of mean and standard deviation.
These two features are actually the most important or the most useful ones when dealing with accelerometer.
This is the reason why we can see the clustering of mean and standard deviation really easily.
These are these clusters represents different users and the colors represents different different activities.

Why these clusters are so differently is again 'cause not only people walk or run differently, but also they were found in the different locations, like maybe in pocket or here or maybe imports this particular case.
The phone was born in Purse and the phone had a lot more vibrations than in the pocket, so that's why this cluster is up here.
OK, from the picture it is clearly seen that if we look for one particular person, the activity is clearly distinguishable.
For example, for person, let's say G running is here and walking is here and sitting is here.
But if we want to build a little more general classifier.
We can expect some problems between walking and running.
We see that cluster the data from walking.
From person, GNC would probably be categorized as running with some simple classifier that uses only mean and standard deviation.
For this reason it was necessary that we include another feature that can classify walking and running.
Better, and this is the dominant frequency.
It is clearly seen that almost.
Every person in our test group had the dominant frequency of walking around 2 Hertz.
And for running around 29 Hertz so this frequency, this dominant frequency feature.
Is really useful to distinguish between walking and running.
We have an explanation for this other small piece which are pretty systematic.
This one for instance also walking.
I think this is just because the free a transformation.
Yeah.
But why they accumulated just?
They're just always.
If you increase the frequency of my two factor of two to get the sum, same information, OK?
So the third step was to select the best classifier.
For this step we have used the Veka toolkit for those who are not familiar with this toolkit.
It's actually a collection of machine learning algorithms, and if you parse your data into RF files, you can easily test your data on different machine learning algorithms.
I have tested it on.
Decision tree, naive Bayes, scanners, neighbors, support vector machine and neural network.
So here are the.
Old here we can see the first group of features called all features.
Here we can see the second one simplified features and here the third one minute standard deviation.
Overall, we can see that simplified feature set gave us a little better result than all feature set as we expected.
And of course even better than mean and standard deviation.
But if we look which feature which algorithm gave us the best result?
Is this actually naive base with 93% of correctly classified objects, so that's why we use naive Bayes to implement with a simple feature set.
I'm so quick experiment.
How well was it?
How good does it work?
The input was around 300 labeled samples and we can see that in 96% the classifier classified it correctly.
Here we can.
This is a confusion matrix where this is the actual data from the activity of running and this is where it was classified.
So 92 samples were classified correctly to rank in walking section.
Similar for walking and sitting.
But we wanted to know how this would work in the real life applications.
So for that reason we have recorded 12 hours of data and so we input it into our classifier and this is.
Result.
Data was actually recorded by me, so I can.
I can explain what was going on at 7:00 AM.
I started to recording at around 8:00 AM.
I went to work.
Actually I went to work with the bicycle, but since I guess cycling is not so.
Doesn't have as many vibrations as running, so the classifier classifieds cycling as walking.
So here we can see a little walking around the office.
It's a working day and here we can see around 1:00.
This is lunch time.
I went to the cafeteria.
I went back and that 5:00 PM I I end up with work and I went home again with the bicycle.
The pattern is.
Really similar, and this part is interesting.
This was actually a little trip to the nearest Hill.
We can see that the work was a little more energetic and that's why some of the samples are classified as running.
But recording data continuously for 12 hours can be a problem for the batteries, so that's why I want it.
We wanted to know how this would work if we would, for example, record data only every 3 minutes for only 10 seconds.
This is the filter data and we can see that almost all activity are recognizable.
Even this lunchtime and here I think it even works better than in this one.
There is 30 Hertz.
Here is one for 10 seconds with no ones for three minutes for 10 seconds.

So for the future work, we will definitely increase the number of recognizable activities for also standing not only sitting and then hiking and cycling and driving, and also shopping can be really well.
Recognizable then we are planning to include some more sensors to achieve more more accuracy like GPS, gyroscope and compass.
Also larger training sets.
Larger testing set not for only for one day, but maybe one week, one month and we have to do a little more research about sampling frequency.
In this case it was 30 Hertz.
Maybe can be lower and window size.
In this case it was 10 seconds as I talked about by that.
Probably it can be also lower, like five or three seconds.
Um, so I would just like to conclude my presentation with question to myself, why this we complicate things.
Why didn't we just use GPS sensor?
Extract the speed and distinguish between walking and running and sitting?
Well?
The first answer is that GPS doesn't work inside and the second answer is if we add some.
Activities activities like cycling and running and driving really slow with the car has more or less the same speed sent only with GPS.
We could not distinguish it and also recording GPS samples would take would take a lot more battery than than accelerometer.
So from this point of view activity recognition with accelerometer data makes sense I guess.
So thank you.
